Miniopterus natalensis, commonly known as the Natal long-fingered bat, is a species of insectivorous bat found in parts of Africa, including South Africa, Eswatini, and Mozambique. This small bat belongs to the family Miniopteridae, a group of bats distinguished by their long, narrow wings and specialized adaptations for fast, agile flight.

The Natal long-fingered bat has a body length of around 9-12 cm and a wingspan of approximately 28-32 cm. Its fur is typically dark brown or black in color, and it has large, rounded ears and a short, blunt muzzle. The species is characterized by its elongated finger bones, which give it the ability to fold its wings compactly against its body during roosting and resting periods.

Miniopterus natalensis is a cave-dwelling species, often found in large colonies within limestone caves, abandoned mines, and other sheltered, dark habitats. These bats are known to be excellent flyers, capable of rapid, directional changes in flight to catch their insect prey, which includes moths, beetles, and other small flying insects.

The Natal long-fingered bat plays an important ecological role as a nocturnal insect predator, contributing to the regulation of insect populations in its native range. The species is classified as Least Concern on the IUCN Red List, but it may face threats from habitat loss, disturbance of roosting sites, and human persecution in some areas.
